Name: On which side are the angels
Name_ann: On which side are the angels

Name: The great greenhouse scare
Mike_comments: so sanguine, there is no challenge at all!

Name: Weather watching
Quotes?: Skeptic view. Need to research long terms effects rather than focusing on details like CO2 "the return of the ice would be worse"

Name: Catastrophe or change?
Sam_comments: CC is only referenced implicitly but the article is quite important I think in setting up Nature's conviction and publishing strategy so I think it should be retained

Name: Nuclear fusion or the sun god?
Name_ann: Nuclear fusion or the sun god

Name: Better treaty is worth waiting for
Name_ann: Better treaty is worth waiting for
Sam_comments: Remove. Mike would agree to remove.  It's tricky because this is an important 70s topic, but it's hard to say climate modification is a CC challenge; it's just listed as part of a warfare convention.
Noam_comments: Agree with Sam. Remove

Name: Carter's energy message
Mike_comments: I think this one *could* be kept, since it sees the CO2 problem in terms of energy technology/policy
Sam_comments: It simply says that CC will have to take a backseat to energy policies so I'm not sure it can be categorised as an energy framing of CC
Noam_comments: Could be kept. Not sure if it should though

Name: Costs and benefits of carbon
Quotes?: Argues from more interdisciplinarity (broadening research beyond climate science)

Name: Towards a mild nuclear winter?
Mike_comments: All about nuclear winter - but is this what we mean by CC?  Mike is happy to keep this.
Sam_comments: Keep, on the basis of the programme providing a baseline for other man-made influences on climate (i.e. does frame a broader CC challenge for science). Which as we know is important in the history of CC modelling.
Noam_comments: Not sure we should keep this in the corpus - no mention of anthropogenic CC

Name: Defining half a global problem
Sam_comments: This is political because climate change is considered to be a challenge for legal instruments even though poverty/development represents a significant issue

Name: How to tackle global calamity
Sam_comments: Although security is key to the article, climate change is more framed in terms of a question of population control and government, which I think is F

Name: Where the world stands on ozone
Name_ann: where the world stands on ozone
Mike_comments: Agreed - keep this one
Sam_comments: Keep, as it clearly frames the paper in terms of the need to develop a similar kind of convention if CO2 emissions become a problem
Noam_comments: Keep because of mention of CO2 at the end

Name: Green politics make more trouble
Sam_comments: Article really on why Thatcher is taking on CC (and envt) to gain votes, but without considering the implications (cost, development)

Name: Uranium bites dust
Mike_comments: Just one brief mention, but agree to keep since it explicitly links CC to nuclear
Sam_comments: Keep, as it frames CC as a challenge that nuclear energy provides an answer to
Noam_comments: Based on our Science coding. I would keep this

Name: We're all greens now
Quotes?: On identity crisis of British green party

Name: Towards a greenhouse convention
Quotes?: interesting argument for gov to take responsibility over ghg

Name: Adirondacks awake
Mike_comments: Review of McKibbin's book - is this an alarmist version of H?

Name: Environmental policy still undefined
Quotes?: Author argues that climate change is given too much prominence

Name: Learning to live in a greenhouse
Name_ann: Learning to live in a greenhouse

Name: The great sky greenhouse
Quotes?: Yes - IPCC authors need to tell their findings to broader professional community before making them publics to avoid embarassment

Name: Towards a greenhouse treaty?
Quotes?: Yes, IPCC will resolve science so the real issue now is political negotiation

Name: What greenhouse convention?
Quotes?: The politics of cataclysmic populism will get us nowhere

Name: Doctrinal fallacies of stewardship
Sam_comments: This article is a critique of no growth, and mentions CC more in passing, but does frame this as part of a broader narrative for why economic growth must continue.

Name: How to organize for the greenhouse
Name_ann: How to organise for the greenhouse

Name: Too much caution on global warming
Name_ann: Too much caution on global warming

Name: Dangers of disappointment at Rio
Quotes?: Yes, really interesting points about Rio

Name: The best global warming treaty yet
Name_ann: The best global warming treaty yet

Name: Two successful weeks at Rio
Quotes?: Yes, real task is least cost
Sam_comments: It's surprising, but when this article discusses CC the emphasis is on least cost solutions as priority

Name: Waiting in the wings
Mike_comments: Agree to keep - fascinating to see how AGW solution is framed as nuclear
Sam_comments: Keep, for the same reason as a previous one that nuclear is the solution to the challenge of CC
Noam_comments: Fine with me

Name: The motor-car as black sheep
Sam_comments: Interesting article that is hard to code because it argues against the car being seen as the greenhouse villain and advocates looking to other things (unspecified) for solutions - I think that puts the ball in F's court (i.e. institutional challenge)

Name: Are fast reactors gone for good?
Name_ann: Are fast reactors gone for good
Sam_comments: CC deemed to be politically unlikely to be tackled, but when it is, nuclear will be the solution

Name: The great Berlin greenhouse compromise
Sam_comments: This article genuinely lists 2 key priorities: ethical and political agreement, and the need for better science. Impossible to split in terms of dominance?

Name: Conflicts of interest on the greenhouse
Name_ann: Conflicts on interest on the greenh..

Name: Don't ban sceptics
Mike_comments: I disagree with Sam here.  I think keep since the editorial argues that env science (ie. CC) needs sceptical voices to be heard so it Frame H
Sam_comments: Remove, as the only reference to CC is reporting on Brown, the editorial itself doesn't present a CC challenge
Noam_comments: While this is a secondary account, I'm inclined to side with Mike because of how explicitly the H framing comes out!

Name: Opportunity in Kyoto for a president's legacy
Name_ann: Opportunity in Kyoto for a president

Name: Cooperation can help get the message across
Name_ann: Cooperation can help to get the

Name: Seizing global warming as an opportunity

Name: A timely boost to research on carbon sequestration
Name_ann: A timely boost to research on carbon

Bush's science flashpoints
Quotes?: About the need for Bush to listen to "science" and recognize evidence

Name: Europe's right approach to energy
Quotes?: not sure which one is dominant

Name: Shooting the messenger
Quotes?: Very good example of H frame

Name: Leadership at Johannesburg
Quotes?: scientists need to lead the way

Name: Media studies for scientists
Quotes?: cc just a small example here

Name: Climate come-uppance delayed
Quotes?: Yes, echoes of Trump and Paris

Name: No way to run a superpower
Name_ann: No way to run a superpower

Name: Yes, we have no energy policy
Name_ann: Yes, we have no energy policy

Name: Clean, green conferencing
Sam_comments: This article is about how offsetting (of a good kind) might be best for scientific conferences hence the reason it's A (an economic fix)

Name: Ignorance is not bliss
Mike_comments: I would agree to keep but if so then it is Frame A economics - it makes this explicit at the end.
Sam_comments: Keep. It is tangential, but it does frame CC as a challenge. My Q is, is it really an economic one or a political one as much as a communication one?
Noam_comments: Have changed primary framing to A. Agree that the economic frame is made explicit at the end.

Name: States versus gases
Sam_comments: This has to be coded F, but really it's about framing CC as a legal issue

Name: Welcome climate bloggers
Quotes?: Encourages climate scientist to blog and reach out

Name: Distributing the costs of climate change
Global reach
Quotes?: More about pb facing UNEP than CC itself

Name: In praise of soft science
Maud_comments: Would keep it, A and G
Mike_comments: I think remove.  CC mentioned only vaguely once as an example, but the thrust of the editorial is too generic to include
Sam_comments: Keep. CC a challenge of human behaviour. Is that A in coding terms? G is needed to deliver on the challenge of behaviour so I think G might be secondary
Noam_comments: Agree with Sam that behavioural framing is probably A. Disagree that we should get rid of this editorial. It clearly problematises CC in a specific way.

Name: A state of flux
Maud_comments: I would keep and frame as H, potentially F too
Mike_comments: Is one sentence here significant enough?  OK to keep?
Sam_comments: Keep. I think it's marginal, but it does set up CC as a communication/skeptic challenge with the political bias sentence.
Noam_comments: Remove. It talks about actions of the Bush Administration without framing CC per se

Name: A warm welcome
Quotes?: Yes, best quotes on religion I've seen

Name: Capturing carbon
Quotes?: Carbon sequestration as only solution for the energy system

Name: Coming in from the cold
Mike_comments: Agree.  Keep this.
Sam_comments: Keep. CC is a political opportunity to gather together Arctic research communities which is clearly seen as the challenge.
Noam_comments: Keep & agree with coding

Name: Reaching a tipping point
Quotes?: Yes - on the notion of tipping point

Name: Special provision
Quotes?: Yes, why Tyndall should be funded (good example of science funding as solution)

Name: The gathering storm
Quotes?: on the politics of science advice

Name: Warming to economics
Quotes?: Great quotes on economics and CC

Name: Brave blue world
Quotes?: Quotes in defence of science funding

Name: Cut the climate antics
Quotes?: On AIT, Gore and policy focus

Name: Light at the end of the tunnel
Name_ann: Light at the end of the tunnel

Name: Off the rails
Sam_comments: A little tricky to code as it presents the airlines emissions challenge without really specifying whether it's primarily economic, behavioural or political

Name: Rising to the climate challenge
Quotes?: On the importance of the IPCC and robust scientific advice

Name: Welcome Nature Geoscience
Mike_comments: Agree.  Keep,.
Sam_comments: Keep. Unlike Welcome Nature CC which I think I read, this one actually sets out the argument for the journal vis-a-vis science as an answer to the challenge of CC.
Noam_comments: Keep

Name: Down on the farms
Quotes?: Yes, interesting points about offshore wind and the military concern

Name: The EPA's tailspin
Mike_comments: Agree to keep, but is this F rather than G?
Sam_comments: Keep. I think it frames the issue of CC as a challenge for scientific administration.
Noam_comments: F as primary? G as secondary?

Name: The next big climate challenge
Quotes?: Yes, on the promise of C prediction

Name: Fair Trade?
Sam_comments: Focus is on European financial crisis and the impact on policies for climate change

Name: After Copenhagen
Quotes?: Great take, argues for more bottom up approaches instead of waiting for a global consensual approach

Name: Caught on camera
Maud_comments: I would keep and frame as H, the challenge is how to communicate
Mike_comments: I disagree.  I think it shows CC as FRame H.  Keep for me
Sam_comments: Remove. Much as I like the editorial and we might keep it qualitatively, it doesn't frame a climate challenge
Noam_comments: Not about CC - about Schneider. I don't know how I feel about this one. Happy either way.

Name: Darwin and culture
Quotes?: On science communication, CC as marginal example
Mike_comments: Agree. Definitely keep.
Sam_comments: Keep. Ironically despite it being a very small reference, it clearly frames the problem of CC as one of public scientific literacy/understanding.
Noam_comments: Agree

Name: Dismal no more
Quotes?: On the role of good scientific advice

Name: The way ahead for polar science
Name_ann: The way ahead for polar science

Name: Time to act
Sam_comments: This lists so many different possibilities, but I think the ultimate challenge is political (commitment from high levels) hence F is the dominant frame.

Name: Transparency needed
Mike_comments: Agree.  Keep.
Sam_comments: Think this should be included as it argues that transparency is essential for all energy projects, if humanity is to tackle energy and climate challenges. But have made it orange to compare to the next one I analysed below.
Noam_comments: Clearly this is about public communication/disclosure. Keep

Name: Cheerleader or watchdog?
Quotes?: On relations between scientists and journalists

Name: Earth's boundaries?
Sam_comments: Does the fact this is about planetary boundaries automatically make it global even though the article really is based around one research team? The intervention is not global so I've marked this 0 but would appreciate a double-check.
Noam_comments: I definitely think it's a 0 (given that it points out to the local variation)

Name: Science is not a spectator sport
Name_ann: Science in not a spectator sport

Name: Calm in a crisis
Sam_comments: Keep. CC is a scientific communication challenge so I think it's H rather than G. It's not more science, but better communication
Noam_comments: Mention of climate science

Name: Out in the cold
Sam_comments: Keep. The CC challenge is the profund changes affecting the poles, to which science is the response. Very limited sidepoint in the article, but it is there.
Noam_comments: It's about polar science & icebreakers

Name: Science subpoenaed
Mike_comments: I would put this as Frame H, not D.
Sam_comments: H dominant in my view; the challenge is framed as one of defeating political machinations in science; secondary G possibly, not convinced about D; attributes 000

Name: Turbines and turbulence
Mike_comments: Wind turbines and rainfall - CC??
Sam_comments: Keep. It does also state wind farms could be a benefit for CC as well as having impacts.

Name: Up in the air
Sam_comments: About the need for better emissions monitoring

Name: An end to gridlock?
Mike_comments: Agree keep.  Quite explicit about the purpose of new tech is lower emissions
Sam_comments: Carbon reductions are a little marginal to the story, but on the other hand it frames energy as a solution to these
Noam_comments: Agree. keep

Name: Wanted: an IPCC for biodiversity
Mike_comments: I would agree with Sam here
Sam_comments: It frames climate change as global and as an economic challenge; so primary is A; could have implied G as secondary; 100 attributes
Noam_comments: Not sure how to code this

Name: A paler shade of green
Quotes?: False distinction between environmental protection and the economy

Name: False economy
Maud_comments: would frame CC as H here
Mike_comments: I think probably keep - since the editorial lauds the WW Vision project for helping 'communication'
Sam_comments: ?? It states that they carried out a study on CC, but it doesn't argue this is a challenge for CC. That said, seeing skepticism turn to consensus implies communication as a challenge. Honestly not sure if this should be kept.
Noam_comments: Mentions opinion poll on views on climate change

Name: Heart of the matter
Quotes?: Doesn't seem to fit in any frame
Mike_comments: I agree.  This is Frame H
Sam_comments: Primary H because Nature feel people need to understand contrarians motives/voices; attributes 000

Name: Home truths
Mike_comments: Agree with Sam.  F with H as secondary.
Sam_comments: This is awkward because most of it describes Nisbet's argument. So I think the challenge is F, because the first paragraph (the editorial voice) frames this as a problem for international treaty making; attributes then are 100
Noam_comments: Tough one to code - is it about communication?

Name: On the rebound
Quotes?: "to put the ghost of Jevons to rest"

Name: Over the limit
Maud_comments: What is this comment about difference between male and female drivers?? Back to the topic: would frame it as A (financial ) and F as secondary, also policy
Mike_comments: Definitley keep - but it could be Frame A, economics
Sam_comments: Keep. I think this is interesting as it frames CC as a challenge around communication (I think), that we need to more clearly delineate between economic, policy skeptics and scientific ones.
Noam_comments: Not sure it should be part of the corpus and not sure how to code

Name: Second chances
Mike_comments: Yes, agree with Sam
Sam_comments: Unless I missed something, CC is referred to as greenhouse gas emission challenges and the hint is delivered through politics. So I think F is primary. A and B are both there in terms of the article, but the explicit climate change references are about international organisations. Attributes 100
Noam_comments: Governance or economic frame?

Name: Seeing REDD
Quotes?: On the rights of indigenous people

Name: Shot with its own gun
Sam_comments: Although this is about dealing with hostile critics, it argues the emphasis is on scientific credibility not poor communication

Name: The mask slips
Quotes?: Yes, on failure of political will

Name: A first step
Noam_comments: "At its heart, this is a scientific challenge..."

Name: A second wind for the president
Name_ann: A second wind for the president

Name: A vote for science
Mike_comments: I agree with Sam on this one
Sam_comments: Keep. I think it frames CC as a challenge that requires more scientific investment (i.e. G) i.e. Obama over Romney. I know it's set up as a political comparison, but I think the editorial argument is for more science funding to solve CC.
Noam_comments: Not sure it should be part of the corpus and not sure how to code

Name: A way to buy time
Quotes?: Yes, energy efficiency as quick fix

Name: Over the line
Quotes?: Yes,interesting Q of honesty in science

Name: Damage control
Mike_comments: Yes, keep.  It is Frame F with G as secondary
Sam_comments: Keep. It argues the primary challenge is one of adaptation (and funding for this) as well as science. Probably F I guess
Noam_comments: About NYC resilience to CC

Name: Plan for the future
Quotes?: We cannot manage what we cannot measure

Name: Science in schools
Mike_comments: Yes, I think it is Frame H.  Very clear challenge (scientists to communicate) and CC is very definitely used as key example
Sam_comments: Is there really enough here to claim it as framing climate change?

Name: The final assessment
Sam_comments: Although about IPCC and science, the conclusion is more political/governmental action

Name: Together we stand
Maud_comments: I would frame this as B, all about Sustainable Dev and CC
Mike_comments: I think development is central here, so Frame B with the others as secondary
Sam_comments: CC is framed as an economic energy challenge but with energy as root cause so I think E Is dominant; I don't think there's a specific policy reference either as it's quite vague about SDGs
Noam_comments: Ok I have settled on B. Development is the key challenge here IMO

Name: Sink or swim?
Noam_comments: "...provide the global data sets required to understand"

Name: Brace for impacts
Maud_comments: I would go for B as it is all about adaptation, but happy with F too
Mike_comments: There are lots of frames here.  One could say adaptation is Frame F institutional/management, with others secondary
Sam_comments: Adaptation (and inequity of adaptation) is the primary challenge and G is used to support it, so B is dominant; the rest are secondary. I'm happy with ethics as a secondary frame.
Noam_comments: I think I side with Mike on this one. To be resolved

Name: Holy cows
Mike_comments: Yes, I would go for Frame G
Sam_comments: Keep. As it frames CC as an urgent challenge for nature conservation. I'm not convinced it's a communication challenge, despite the poster child point; it's potentially more about monitoring which I guess would be G
Noam_comments: About walruses

Name: Honest brokers
Quotes?: Yes, on collective aspect of CC

Name: People power
Quotes?: Climate models must quantify society's response to climate change

Name: Support our buoys

Sam_comments: Keep. The subtitle in itself sets up the challenge of CC to be resolved through science
Noam_comments: About monitoring the Pacific

Sam_comments: Keep. Yes I think there's just enough on how CC understanding can be improved through more science

Name: Goals Galore

Noam_comments: Not sure it should be part of the corpus and not sure how to code

Name: No strings

Sam_comments: Climate change barely framed as an issue, but transparency is key, so I think H is the implied challenge.

Quotes?: Large scale CSS as the solution

Will the World Come to a Horrible End?
